questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents with a painless swelling in the right supraorbital region that has been gradually progressing over the past year. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
A dermoid cyst is the most likely diagnosis. This is a congenital choristoma (normal tissue in an abnormal location) that arises from ectodermal tissue trapped along embryonic suture lines. The presentation of a painless, slow-growing, smooth, mobile mass in the uperior temporal (supraorbital) region of the orbit (near the frontozygomatic suture) in a child or young adult is classic for a dermoid cyst.

Explanation of other options:

Lacrimal gland mass (Option A): Usually presents superolateral, may be painful or associated with inflammatory signs, and can be neoplastic or inflammatory. Gradual, painless swelling without other signs is less typical.

Hemangioma (Option C): Typically appears in infancy, is compressible, may blanch, and often regresses spontaneously. Rarely presents as a slowly enlarging lesion in adolescence.

Epidermoid cyst (Option D): Rare in the orbit, usually slow-growing, firm, and not typically localized to suture lines like dermoid cysts.

questions.text: A patient presents with guttate lesions in one eye and bullous keratopathy in the other eye. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical picture is classic for Fuchs endothelial dystrophy, a bilateral but often asymmetric disease of the corneal endothelium. The cornea guttata in one eye represents the early stage, characterized by abnormal excrescences on Descemet's membrane. The bullous keratopathy in the other eye represents the advanced, decompensated stage where endothelial cell failure leads to corneal edema, epithelial blisters, and pain.

Explanation of Other Options:

Trachoma (Option A): This is an infectious disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis and is characterized by follicular conjunctivitis, conjunctival scarring (Arlt's line), pannus, Herbert's pits, and trichiasis, not cornea guttata.

Herpes keratitis (Option B): Herpetic keratitis presents with dendritic or geographic ulcers, stromal scarring, and decreased corneal sensation, not guttata or bullous keratopathy. It is usually unilateral.

Keratoconus (Option D): It is a non-inflammatory ectatic disorder with conical protrusion of cornea, thinning, Fleischer's ring, Vogt's striae and Munson's sign, not guttata or bullous keratopathy.

choices.text: Ethmoidal sinusitis is the most common source of infection in all age groups
Topical broad-spectrum antibiotics are the mainstay of treatment
The inflammation is restricted anterior to the orbital wall
Patients characteristically present with proptosis, blurring of vision, normal pupillary and ocular movements

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding orbital cellulitis is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Orbital cellulitis is an infection of the soft tissues posterior to the orbital septum, most commonly arising from the contiguous spread of infection from adjacent paranasal sinuses. Due to its proximity and separation only by the very thin lamina papyracea, the ethmoid sinus is the most frequent origin of this sight-threatening infection.

Key Takeaway:

choices.text: Glaucomflecken with acute angle closure glaucoma

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with complaints of a decrease in vision. There were white deposits on the anterior lens surface, seen during slit lamp examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image displays the pathognomonic "target" or "bull's eye" sign, which is the hallmark finding of Pseudoexfoliation (PEX) syndrome.

Pseudoexfoliation Syndrome (PEX):

PEX is a systemic disorder of elastic fibers, strongly linked to the LOXL1gene, where a distinctive grey-white fibrillar material is deposited on ocular and systemic tissues. It is a critical diagnosis to make due to its strong association with aggressive glaucoma and cataract surgery complications.

1. Key Diagnostic Signs (Slit-Lamp Examination)

The diagnosis is primarily made by identifying the pathognomonic PEX material and its effects on the anterior segment.

2. Most significant complication: Pseudoexfoliative Glaucoma (PXG)

3. Systemic Associations

While the ocular findings dominate, PEX is a systemic condition.

Systemic Elastosis: PEX material has been identified in the skin, heart, lungs, and blood vessels.

Explanation of Other Options:

Glaucomflecken with acute angle closure glaucoma (Option A):
Glaucomflecken are anterior subcapsular lens opacities resulting from acute IOP spikes. Usually associated with corneal edema, pain, and acute angle closure signs, not the characteristic white fibrillar deposits.

Iritis with pupillary deposits (Option C):
In iritis (anterior uveitis), deposits consist of inflammatory cells or fibrin that can lead to adhesions (synechiae). The classic finding is keratic precipitates on the corneal endothelium or pupillary margins, not fibrillar material on the lens capsule.

Anterior capsule opacification (Option D):
This occurs post-cataract surgery, with fibrotic opacification of the anterior capsule, unlike primary fibrillar deposits seen in PXS.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is treated using the modality shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

INTACS (Intrastromal Corneal Ring Segments - ICRS) are small PMMA (polymethyl methacrylate) semicircular ring segments, usually 2 rings, implanted into the mid-peripheral corneal stroma.

  • Mechanism of action: They flatten the central cornea by shortening the arc length of corneal lamellae in the implanted zone, thereby reducing ectasia and irregular astigmatism.
  • Indications:
    • Keratoconus (mild to moderate): Improves visual acuity in patients intolerant to contact lenses and not yet requiring keratoplasty.
    • Low myopia (up to -5.0 D): By flattening the cornea, INTACS can also correct small degrees of refractive myopia.

Note: INTACS improve vision and corneal shape but do not halt progression of keratoconus. Corneal collagen cross-linking (CXL) is required to prevent disease progression.

Explanation of other options:

Keratoglobus (Option B) is a diffuse thinning of the cornea with a globular shape. INTACS are not effective here; surgical options include lamellar or penetrating keratoplasty.

Vogt's limb striae (Option C) are fine vertical stress lines in the deep stroma/Descemet's membrane seen in keratoconus, which disappear with pressure on the globe. They are a sign, not a condition treated by INTACS.

Corneal dystrophy (Option D) is a genetic, bilateral, progressive condition managed with keratoplasty in advanced stages. INTACS have no role.

References:

Intracorneal Ring Segment Implantation in the Management of Keratoconus: An Evidence-Based Approach - PMC

questions.text: Binocular single vision consists of which of the following components, corresponding to Image A and Image B, respectively?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The images illustrate the first two hierarchical grades of binocular single vision.

  • Image A: Tests Simultaneous Perception, which is Grade I BSV.
  • Image B: Tests Fusion, which is Grade II BSV.

Grades of Binocular Single Vision (Worth's Grades):

Binocular Single Vision (BSV) is the ability of the brain to fuse the images from both eyes into a single, three-dimensional perception. As described by Worth, it is a hierarchical function consisting of three distinct grades, which are classically tested using a synoptophore.
